div.p:
Transcribed 6 November 1992.
[...] we need a note to explain ellipsis
MRS 202/387 special bundle, collector, Archives of the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Sydney.

Re. the Eucalypts of which I gave no specific name yet, let me assure you that it is not owing to carelessness or neglect, that I have not send the names. I am as much interested as any one to get them, for I firmly believe, that when ones the gums (kinos) are properly investigated each will give different distinct characteristics. The matter stands as follows: I have sent fruiting and flowering specimens with leaves in the young state of the following Eucalypts to the Baron: Ribbon Gum from the coast; Ribbon or Manna Gum from the high tableland; white Iron Bark or Mountain Ash and Peppermint, and in each instance the Baron has decided the species to be Euc. amygdalina !!, though in each instance I have given characteristics about the bark wether deciduous or persistent, rough, furrowed or smooth, wether deciduous on the limbs only as in white Iron Bark or Mountain Ash; also some remarks about their timbers, and in each instance I have given the local name, but that was his decision Euc. amygdalina var. As I was afraid this might bring confusion into your department, and wishing to do my work well, I decided to wait until I would send another supply of the above species to Baron von Müller pointing out more forcibly the vast difference between leaves, barks and timber, as well as time of flowering and once more await the result, and then give you the names. This is the only reason I did not give the specific names yet, else I might have given the usual names (always on doubtful authority) White Iron Bark or Mountain Ash=Euc. crebra; Peppermint=Euc. amygdalina; Ribbon Gum from the coast Euc. saligna.
